title: An integrated system for manpower planning
New accounting rules and acquisition planning
Husky's Long-Range Planning Model
container-title: Fall Meeting of the Society of Petroleum Engineers of AIME
items.abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>This paper describes the long range planning process in Husky and its use of planning process in Husky and its use of computers and especially a computer simulation model which compiles forecast data from multiple departments/subsidiaries into a finished long range plan. The model performs all the arithmetic calculations involved performs all the arithmetic calculations involved in consolidating basic input data to furnish consolidated cash flow, earnings, earnings per share, capital requirements, debt and per share, capital requirements, debt and interest schedules as well as certain operating data for a six year period. It permits easy insertion of new variables, which may represent a proposed acquisition or simply an alternate method of operating, and quickly determines the net effect of the variables.</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Introduction</jats:p>
               <jats:p>As one Husky executive put it, "Planning is making things happen." And, around Husky this concept of planning has been taken very seriously since 1961 when the first formal written plan was prepared. It consisted of a dozen pages of charts and other data in summarized form. Today's plan contains over 60 tables, covering all major financial and operating aspects of each department as well as consolidated totals. The Planning and Economics Department, who is Planning and Economics Department, who is responsible for developing plans, is made up of a Manager, who has direct access to the President, one Planning Coordinator, who President, one Planning Coordinator, who assembles and formulates various data into the Long Range Plan model, and a Coordinator of Operations Research, who applies computer techniques to solve complex planning and economic problems. Because of planning and economic problems. Because of computer usage, the equivalent of one-half manpower unit is devoted to the mechanics of plan preparation at the corporate level. plan preparation at the corporate level. Planning in Husky consists of a budget year plus five years of the long range plan. This process consists of three major activities:</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Top management defines the overallgoals and objectives of the company, including earnings and earnings pershare growth.</jats:p>

title: Planning Tire Production
items.abstract: <jats:p> An outline of the tire production process is given. A planning model is discussed and an application is made to the planning of tire production (both long and short term). Planning for finished tires, green tires and for components is included as the model is developed. A multi-item production planning program is presented for finished tires and this is expanded to an assembly model with precedences for green tires and for components. </jats:p>

Pluralistic Planning within the Criminal Justice System
items.abstract: <jats:p> If urban complexes are to become functioning entities with a cohesive sense of purpose, central and regional planning will be necessary to achieve coordination and a sense of unity. Such planning, however, demands the cooperation and allegiance of all the municipal fragments of a region and must be on a human scale, taking into account not only the smaller neighborhood group but the individual as well. To apply this same premise to institutions within the criminal justice system requires that the "client," who is involuntarily caught up in the system's bureaucracies, be given a chance to articulate his own evaluation of himself and his problem, thus participating in planning his future. </jats:p>

title: The Modern Metropolis: Its Origins, Growth, Characteristics, and Planning
Fertility and Family Planning in Africa
container-title: The Journal of Modern African Studies
items.abstract: <jats:p>As the result of recent demographic research, we now have a reasonable basis for estimating rates of birth, death, and population growth in subSaharan Africa. These findings suggest that fertility is higher, and mortality lower, than had previously been assumed. This combination of high fertility and declining mortality implies a high rate of population growth. The compatibility of such a growth rate with existing plans for social and economic development is doubtful. This article examines the findings and issues, and seeks to determine the feasibility of population control in sub-Saharan Africa.</jats:p>

Indicative Planning—The New Zealand Experience
items.abstract: <jats:p>It is based on a paper presented to the 1st Conference of Australian and New Zealand Economists, in Melbourne, May 1970. The writer is greatly indebted to help given by Mr. W. A. E. Green, Assistant Secretary to the Treasury, in the preparation of this paper. Mr. Green is head of the Planning Division of the Treasury.</jats:p>

title: Research planning diagrams
items.abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>A research planning diagram notation is introduced. It is based on computer programming flow charts and has a number of advantages over the conventional arrow diagram method. The notation lends itself to a straightforward quantitative analysis which yields probabilistic time and cost information in a form suitable for use in project planning, selection or control. Two current research programmes are examined as illustrations of RPD methods.</jats:p>
